title: 112_hr710
content: The Act may be cited as the "Telework Tax Incentive Act." The Congress finds that billions of dollars are spent annually on transportation needs, with congestion on roads costing over $87 million in 2007. On-road vehicles contributed 31.9% of nitrogen oxide emissions in 2008. Teleworking could save 450 million barrels of oil, reduce greenhouse gases by 84 million tons, and cut highway maintenance costs by over $3 billion annually. The average American daily commute is 51 minutes. The National Science Foundation found that teleworking increased productivity by 87 percent. In recent years, there has been a marked expansion of teleworking in the United States, with 76 percent of private sector employers now providing technical support for remote workers. Federal IT professionals reported that their agencies offer technical support for teleworkers. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR TELEWORKING. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section for a teleworking credit. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for qualified teleworking expenses, capped at $1,000 per individual teleworker for a full taxable year. The credit is reduced proportionally for individuals teleworking for less than a full year. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for qualified teleworking expenses. An individual is considered to be in a teleworking arrangement if subject to it for any day of the month. Definitions include eligible taxpayer as an individual or employer in a teleworking arrangement, and teleworking arrangement as working remotely for at least 75 days per year. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows eligible taxpayers to claim a credit for qualified teleworking expenses. Telework is defined as performing work using electronic information technologies to reduce or eliminate the commute to a traditional worksite. Qualified teleworking expenses include furnishings and electronic equipment used for teleworking. The tax credit allowable for any taxable year is limited by the regular tax amount. The tax credit for qualified teleworking expenses is limited by the regular tax amount and any excess can be carried forward to the next taxable year. Special rules include reducing the basis of property by the credit amount and potential recapture by the Secretary through regulations. The Secretary can recapture the benefit of any credit for property no longer eligible. No credit for property used outside the US or if taxpayer elects not to apply. No double benefits allowed. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow credits under specific sections. A new paragraph is added to address credits allowed under section 30E. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. Section 30E introduces a teleworking credit, effective for expenses incurred after the enactment date, applicable to taxable years thereafter.
